name: Thiothixene
summary: Thiothixene (Navane) is a first-generation antipsychotic used to manage schizophrenia symptoms.
description: Thiothixene, marketed under the brand name Navane, is a high-potency first-generation (typical) antipsychotic in the thioxanthene class. It primarily exerts its effects by antagonizing dopamine D2 receptors in the brain, which helps reduce psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, and thought disorders. Due to its potency, it is effective at relatively low doses but carries a higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects. It is used mainly for the treatment of schizophrenia and is not considered a first-line therapy today due to the availability of second-generation antipsychotics with more favorable side effect profiles.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to thiothixene or other thioxanthenes

sections.text: Blocks postsynaptic dopamine D2 receptors in the mesolimbic pathway, reducing positive psychotic symptoms; also exhibits some antagonism at alpha-adrenergic and histamine H1 receptors.

adult.oral: Initial: 2 mg three times daily; may increase by 2–4 mg/day at intervals of several days; usual maintenance dose: 20–30 mg/day in divided doses; maximum: 60 mg/day.

pediatric.oral: Safety and efficacy not established for pediatric patients.

sections.text: Initial symptom improvement may occur within several days; full therapeutic effect may take several weeks.

other: Increased mortality in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis
Risk of extrapyramidal symptoms and tardive dyskinesia
Monitor for signs of neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Caution in patients with cardiovascular disease or seizure disorders

items: Monitor for extrapyramidal symptoms and tardive dyskinesia

sections.pregnancy: Use only if potential benefits justify potential risks to fetus
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; consider discontinuing nursing or drug
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity to adverse effects; use lower initial doses

sections.text: Gradual tapering recommended to minimize withdrawal symptoms and avoid rapid relapse.

items: High-potency typical antipsychotic, effective at low doses
Higher risk of movement disorders compared to atypical antipsychotics
Not commonly used as first-line therapy in modern practice
